The hotel was prepared for our arrival, made special transportation arrangements for us, and we were able to truly enjoy our stay - one morning I slept in until noon as it was so quiet, and this never happens at hotels for me! I did sense it catered more to business travelers than vacation travelers, however, this does not deter me from returning and may in fact hav enhanced the paceful atmosphere and great customer service. We hope to return next year.

Reviews.Title: “A place to avoid, especially on business”
Reviews.Author: javelin98
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Town and Country Hotel for a conference, and I absolutely will never willingly set foot here again; in fact, I'm also recommending to my employer that we never schedule another seminar there. I hadn't read any reviews whatsoever about the place before heading there, so I didn't have any preconceived notions about what I would find, other than the pictures on the hotel's website. Needless to say, the hotel is completely unacceptable as a business destination. So, where to begin... * Accommodations The room we stayed in was in one of the hotel's two towers, known as the Regency. The hotel was decrepit. Everywhere you look, paint is scraped and chipped, lightbulbs are burnt out (and allowed to stay that way), windows have dirt in the corners, there are dings in the walls and door jambs, and other such problems. Our room itself has obviously not been updated since the late 80's, to include the comforter, which was faded and frayed. The bathroom is lit by two dim bulbs, which is fine, since brighter light would have drawn even more attention to the stained bathtub, yellowed and peeling grout, and rusty hinges on the door. The door itself looks like it has been repeatedly urinated on, as it is streaked yellow. The air conditioning in our room was so pitiful that we ran it non-stop from the time we arrived to the time we left, and it was never able to bring the room temp below 72Âº. It was also unable to remove the mugginess from the air. We slept with the window open the first night, but, sad to say, our room faced the San Diego Herald-Tribune loading docks, so at 3:30 AM we were assailed with the crash of tractor-trailers backing up to receive shipments of newspapers. The window stayed closed after that. The grounds were beautiful, with rose bushes everywhere, and arbors, trellises, and cute little architectural touches in abundance. Of course, many of those touches, such as ornamental scrollwork, were straight from Home Depot and simply glued in place and painted; they were often askew or chipped and peeling. It was the equivalent of adding as much garnish to a dinner plate as possible to try and hide the fact that the main course was only so much boiled shoe-leather. In addition to everything else, our toilet stopped flushing on the second day. After we called maintenance to fix it, it wouldn't stop flushing. It's feast or famine at the Town & Country. Speaking of famine... * Food Business travelers and convention-goers are usually on a time crunch, as they have only so much time to eat and then be back at the next session or class. The food service at the hotel was so slow that a number of us had to skip meals or eat cold cuts from the deli; when you have only an hour and it takes 40 minutes to get just your drinks, there is a problem. The food was also sub-par; the breakfast buffet at the Terrace Cafe is to be avoided at all costs. The food is cold, rubbery, and of a quality well below that of most fast-food places. The ribs at Kelly's Steakhouse were overdone and dried out, as was the BBQ chicken; the only thing worth eating was the appetizer. Charlie's Bar & Grill was agonizingly slow and overpriced; $13 hamburgers and expensive sodas can quickly eat up your per-diem allowance. * Connectivity As a business traveler, it is essential to stay connected to the office, and Internet access is a key part of that for anyone operating in the 21st century. Here, too, the Town and Country was a let-down. With no wired access, you are forced to purchase ($3 an hour or $10 for 24 hours) wi-fi access through a vendor called LodgeNet. However, the access was so spotty that I was unable to reliably check email, and had to spend over ninety minutes on the phone with LodgeNet tech support to even get connected. * Staff The front-office staff were professional to the point of being brusque, but I only had to deal with them rarely. The waitstaff at Kelly's were utterly clueless, even to the point of failing to unlock the front door on time (we had to go in through the lounge and then tell them that the door was still locked). The waitstaff at Charlie's were arrogant and ignorant of the needs of the customers. The only two places I found excellent staff were at the Trellises restaurant and the in the housekeeping staff. At Trellises, both Angelica and Jesus, and a third gentleman whose name I didn't catch, were charming and responsive, and the food was excellent. As for the housekeeping staff, they did an excellent job with what they had to work with, and our housekeeper took extra special care with my boys' stuffed animals and even hung our wet swimsuits back up after having cleaned the bathroom. * Conclusions Overall, the front-line staff are doing the best they can in the absence of involved and commited top management, which may either be uninterested or incapable of improving the place. The Town and Country has the feeling of a sinking cruise liner; the band is still playing, but the ship is getting lower and lower in the water, and it is only a matter of time before it slips beneath the waves. Unless it is saved by a rescuer with an infusion of cash and competence, the Town and Country does not have much longer to live. I have already sent a note to our central education office (of a government agency with 160,000 employees) asking them to avoid scheduling us at this hotel in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Average Stay”
Reviews.Author: noslengnow
Reviews.Content: Stayed here as part of the San Diego Comic Con room block. A pretty standard hotel stay. Nothing major to complain about. Check-in took about 10 minutes. Parked in the rear lot, which was closer to where our room was. Parking fee was normal (we're from San Francisco Bay Area so we're used to paying for parking rather than expecting it to be free). Hotel room was small and very dated decor (country style) but for us it was just a place to sleep and rest so we didn't much mind the decor. Common walls between rooms are very thin though and if you have neighbors it can definitely be an issue. The location is convenient to the San Diego Trolley and buses plus a mall as well. We took advantage of the trolley location to get to Downtown San Diego and it was pretty convenient. Checkout as a bit weird though. We attempted to checkout via the television system and it told us that we couldn't check out through that until 11:10 a.m., which is 10 minutes beyond the actual check out time. We ended up driving back up to the lobby and checking out there. The line was 5 or 6 people deep so it took about 15 minutes. All told, driving back to the front and waiting in line probably used up 20 to 25 minutes that we could saved had the television checkout been working properly. Overall minor quibbles though. The convenient location for us definitely was a plus in an otherwise average hotel stay.

Reviews.Title: “Don't waste your time here--go elsewhere on Hotel Circle”
Reviews.Author: CincinnatiTrav_l_r
Reviews.Content: Stayed here with a previous conference a few years back--even staying on the company's dime, I would absolutely not recommend this "resort" (?). See reasons below: Check-in debacle: Checked in at 10 p.m. with two young children to find out that they didn't have "a room with a bed" available for us until the following day. Yes, folks, there are indeed hotel rooms without beds?!?!? Not to mention that the room had been reserved for nearly two months, so what happened to our room? Okay, whatever...the kids and I are tired from being in planes and airports for the past 6 hours. Have to wait for the only bellhop in the place (yes, only one on a busy Saturday night and the place was hopping). He takes a large group off to their room--we can't walk to ours w/ our bags and a brass luggage cart because the staff "can't allow guests to use them" (oddly enough, they stay chained up to posts around the property). So we wait, and wait...and wait some more. The 6 minutes slowly turned into 25 minutes :( Ugh...tired, grumpy kids... Make it to the bed-less hotel room (via golf cart because it's all of a 2-minute ride and all) and they have a portable cot/bed delivered. There is a pullout sofa bed in the room, but it's so paper thin and uncomfortable that we are forced to actually rearrange heavy furniture in this room so that my youngest can sleep on two overstuffed chairs that are facing each other. Sigh... Paid $35 for two kids' buffets and 1 adult buffet for breakfast the next morning since we were all starving from our travels. The food was below par, although the service was great. I found this to be true throughout the stay. The maids and waitstaff were courteous and friendly, while the "professional" staff up front could learn some customer service lessons from these hardworking folks! Honestly!!!! To add insult to injury, I make it over to the supposed state-of-the-art workout facility (I can't vouch for this because I didn't actually go into it OR see anyone using it at any point in passing by) on the grounds inside of the day spa (also, not busy) to be greeted by the less-than-enthusiastic desk person by, "Oh, are you staying here with a conference?" I reply with, "Well, yes I am." Then: "Oh, they must have forgotten to tell you about the fee for use: $8/day." WHAT??? I'm paying $14 per day to park, ungodly markup on ho-hum food, overpriced (not to mention old and run-down furnishings in the) room, and now I'm nickle-and-dimed to workout??? I immediately left, of course, only to watch another fellow walk in and right back out. Who pays to use a treadmill at a hotel? I'm sure the Vagabond Inn around the corner has a free workout facility. In the end, I'm sure the management will kindly thank me for my feedback and apologetically promise to look into the issues I raised (as you've probably read in the other 150+ previous reviews). But, it's obvious to anyone and everyone reading these that the management is NOT willing to follow through with this because the same complaints would not be consistently arising. Okay, management, let's here a real game plan on turning this place around?!?!?! All in all, save your money and stay somewhere else on Hotel Circle. Everything in this area is convenient and accessible, not just the Town & Country. Believe me...I gave it a second chance and will NOT make it a third!

Reviews.Title: “Sitting here now.... in my T&C Resort room.”
Reviews.Author: tyler5921
Reviews.Content: So I am sitting here in the Town & Country resort room that was booked for me by my company. I have to say that the grounds are amazing, beautiful, and well taken care of. I wish the rooms were as well taken care of as the rooms. The rooms are outdated, old, and need some TLC. The arm chair i'm sitting in is lumpy, and old. So is the bed I had last night. LUMPY and OLD. You guys need new beds. Every high-end hotel or even budget hotels are getting new beds these days. Even the Comfort Inns and Quality Inns. For me, if the bed is great, than the room itself is not so important. But, since the bed is bad, I look to other things inside the room to off-set the bad bed. This doesn't seem to be happening. :-( Furniture is old and worn out. Towels, small, and not very thirsty. TV is old, and needs more channels. Bravo, etc... Room is NOT private at all, I am facing the parking lot with sheer curtains. You can totally see in at night. Not good for changing clothes or just after a shower. I don't like closed windows, or cover windows, so this is a problem. I asked them for a more private room, but they said that they didn't have any other rooms, and that it would be better to call the next day. I haven't called yet because I'm kind of settled here already, but would still entertain something else. I asked the desk clerk last night to make a note of it, but NO ONE called me today to see if I still wanted to change. I justed to work in hotels, and if we had a note like that, we would have called them to see if they wanted to change rooms, accommodated them, and sold their old room to someone else. I did ask for a nicer room when we checked in. I was educated on types of rooms from their website, and saw one I liked. But was told the one I wanted wasn't in a good place... Well, I am looking at 20 cars out my window right at this very moment. Is that good? I think it could be better. PLUS it's loud. People constantly walk by talking, yelling, or just making noise as they walk. Not very relaxing. I am surprised at the spa/gym. They charge for those. $10/day for the gym and NO AMMENITIES. or $25 for 3 day. I was told too, that 3 day gym "membership" with sauna, hot tub, and steam was $65... OUTRAGEOUS! These things should be included with the gym price - regardless. There's an advertisement in the rooms for the Spa and gym - sounds and reads like hot tub, steam, sauna should be included. No mention of PRICE or daily fees on the card in the room. UGH! And you wonder why there's no one there... This place has 5 or so restaurants. I went to one last night, the Terrace. Food is diner-y. That's okay, it was 10pm when I checked in last night. Haven't been to any of the others yet. I'll follow up with more later if I can. Oh, the windows don't reall open either. they are just louvered on the outside and windows on the inside. Not much flow through with those. Could use another window. or windows that OPEN. Speaking of open windows, the A/C is horrible! Doesn't really work. Works similar to a swamp cooler. Kinda cools, but not really. Anyway, I'm in room 3250. If you decide to stay here, just beware of the noise in this room... VERY NOISY. Thanks! Tyler

Reviews.Title: “Met my expectations”
Reviews.Author: mclanea
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Town & Country for 8 days on business with my family. After reading lots of reviews I was prepared for the worst. In actuality, it isn't a horrible place to stay. - The rooms are adequate and clean. Notice I didn't say "spacious" as they are quite small if you have a family with you. (We had 2 adults, 2 kids) If you were by yourself the room would be large enough. There are no amenities in the rooms. No fridge! You are getting beds, a TV, a dresser, and a bathroom. That's it. - The property. It is well maintained. The biggest issue is that the layout is horrid. We were there for 8 days and got lost on the way to check out! It wasn't just me... we spent a lot of time trying to help people who were lost. - Our rate included breakfast at the buffet. If you ate it one day it would be great. But after 7 of them we were tired of the same breakfast every morning. Also, some days the kids were free and other times were charged. Likewise, the buffet wasn't included in the cost of our rate as we were charged tax on it! (Not like at typical places that include breakfast bars, really odd.) - Parking, $8/day adds up. You don't pay for parking at other nearby hotels. - Service staff. They were really professional. In fact, TOO professional for me. We at the same place every morning for 7 days. Each morning they pretended like they hadn't seen us before. I mean seriously... I stop at Starbucks more than 2 days in a row and they remember me. What's up with that? - The creepy painting in nearly every room is world famous. They can't get rid of it now. http://kristenmclane.com/2008/07/23/wordless-wednesday-creepy-girl/ All of that said, we had a decent time. If you forget about the word "resort" and just treat the hotel like camp... you'll like it. Our kids loved that it had a few pools to chose from. It was conveniently located. And the price was very reasonable.

Reviews.Title: “Exceeded expectations!”
Reviews.Author: jcj34
Reviews.Content: Having booked on Priceline we were disappointed to read the negative reviews on Town and Country. Needless to say, we arrived with low expectations. After a seamless and courteous check-in we were directed to our room and, although a bit outdated, the room was clean and in a great location. I'm incredibily surprised to read reviews that this isn't necessarily a family friendly property. To the contrary, it was perfect. The day we arrived we found out that they were playing Ratattouille on their garden lawn that evening complete with free popcorn and dollar snacks ... what a perfect way to begin our vacation. Thanks Town and Country for exceeding our expectations.

Reviews.Title: “Bait & Switch Rates”
Reviews.Author: smtravelor
Reviews.Content: Booked room in Feb 2008 for a business conference in May 2008 and received the confimation. When I checked out they told me that my billing was "routed" to someone else for billing. I requested an invoice and it was blank. They could not tell who the bill went to. Two weeks later it was posted to my VISA bill, but at a higher rate than it was booked for. I contacted Town and Country and was told they had a rate increase between when I booked the room and stayed so I have to pay the higher rate. I am currently disputing the extra charges with my VISA company and filed a complaint with BBB. Outdated and not very clean. I would not recommend this place to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “Never return to Town and Country”
Reviews.Author: tnstravel
Reviews.Content: Booked the location for a conference and was quoted/sent a price of $129.00 a night plus taxes. Upon check-out, not prior to arrival or even upon arrival, check-out was told the price had been raised to $139.00 a night, with no arguement just that fact that the price increase occured since the original quote. Once arrived at location was given a small room that appeared to be from the 70's era with no upgrades, the room had never been cleaned since the person before us. Attempted to change rooms and contact employees with over a 1.5 hour wait. Eventually moved to a handicap room that did not appear much better. Others traveling with us, did not have room cleaned for 4 days, with no one showing to clean room. On last day the maid attempted to come in room to clean, not knowing I was checking out, I am sure she would have just cleaned and not changed the sheets or anything. This place was overall horrible. I would never come here again or allow anyone I know to stay at this location.

Reviews.Title: “A great time at the Town and Country!”
Reviews.Author: Brittanicus
Reviews.Content: In May 2008, the Mariner/Marlin Association, an affinity group of pilots and aircrews who once flew in U.S. Navy seaplanes such as the Martin PBM and the Martin Marlin, held its annual convention at the Town & Country Resort in San Diego. Though I was familiar with San Diego, I was unaware of the resort located at 500 Hotel Circle in San Diego, CA. Over the years, I have traveled to many parts of the world, especially Europe and the Far East but I have never once found an establishment with such a uniformly well-trained and friendly staff. Never do you have the feeling that anyone is doing you a favor in responding to your concerns. This was amazing to me in a staff that runs close to 1500 people. In addition, the resort is the most beatifully landscaped that I have ever visited and the myriad of plants is meticulously maintained by an army of gardeners. The resort has numerous convention facilities and several excellent restaurants but is also a good place for a simple getaway. Since it is not new, having been in existence since 1953, it might not appeal to the 'Belaggio' set but renovation and addition of new buildings goes on annually and the existing buildings are well maintained. Everyone at the convention loved the place! Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Awful and old..”
Reviews.Author: SanDiegoSkyler
Reviews.Content: I have stayed there several times over the years. There is constant construction and the rooms are outdated. Plus there are hidden fees even in the restaurants that is not included in room prices. I ran into the owner while staying with family and they treated us very rude. I will never stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “More than what people expect”
Reviews.Author: skynsidhawaii
Reviews.Content: Like everyone else, I was here for a conference since it is right next to the conference center. The first night I got there, they stated that we would be put in to a suite with a couch bed (translation: semisuite) and that we would have to leave the room the next day and move into a regular room. Although the room was really nice and had an outside patio that goes to the pool, the inconvenience of having to check out and check in did not set well with me, especially when I had a seminar in the morning that I needed to attend to. However, they did take some responsibility and redeemed themselves by offering me and my wife a password for free internet use access (which is $10.00 per day value) and since I just bought a macbook the day before, my wife was happy with that. Mind you, other than the check in process, the hotel is a very nice place to stay. They take good care of their area and their gardens and the paths/walkways were gorgeous with a splendid assortment of roses, plants, and fountains fixated all over the place which would make any high school prom want to book this place. It is, funny to say, a labyrinth of twists and turns (and actually a dead end in one area between the pool/check in lobby) which makes you feel like you are in Frances Hodgson Burnett's "The Secret Garden" rather than a hotel resort. Also, as you and as you cross though the bridge to the behind the hotel to go through the Fashion Valley Mall (a superb outdoor mall!), you have to cross the small San Diego river. People just pass by it to go to the mall, but it is a really nice area with ducks waddling around and squirrels going to and fro the area as a more natural California scene from balboa park (which is driving distance to the area). For the two rooms that I stayed, they were really nice. The suite was furnished with a basic kitchenette of a microwave and an empty compact refrigerator which was wasnâ€™t stocked with drinks where the hotel would charge you up the ying yang for (although they offer a litter of aquafina for a $2.50 convenience charge). The dÃ©cor of the area was really nice with vases and plants and an outside patio to the pool. The second room that I stayed in was a regular one bedroom king size room equipped with the standard amenities. The inside room had a lovely blue theme and bed was comfortable with a nice view being on the third floor. Now, if you have the money for the high rollers, if you get a presidential suite on the tenth floor like my boss had, you will be sitting in first class with Donald Trump. Equipped with a nice indoor bar, ample space to throw an executive party and a gorgeous view of the resort, seeing this room was definitely one of the highlights of my trip. They even have a little potted tree bush the size of a tiny christmas on the left and right side of the doorway before you enter the room, now that's class! The staff was very competent in what they do and was very friendly and accommodating in whatever I needed. My family sent me a special package, and the people in the front desk were very helpful in assisting me to get my package safely and securely. It was funny because when I left the last day, the guy that helped in for the bell hop area next to the front desk remembered me and waived good bye to me, and that is the personalized service that I enjoy. All in all, the Town and Country is a wonderful place to stay. I think that they can get overbooked due to the proximity of being next to the conference center, but otherwise, it was really good experience for me and would recommend it to my friend, especially if they can afford the presidential suites. They would definitely get their moneys worth!

Reviews.Title: “Hotel just seems tired.”
Reviews.Author: Rivergirl100
Reviews.Content: Like everyone else, I was there for a convention. And while the room was fine, the whole place just had a vaguely sad, worn-out feeling to it. Pehaps its just because it was overcast while I was there, or maybe because this is obviously not a new facility. It just seemed slightly depressed. I stayed in the big tower building. The room was quite adequate, and included a balcony (so you could smoke if you liked.) I know that improvements were being made on other floors, and while I suspect I was in an improved room, it still had a weary feeling to it. The showerhead was indeed low enough that I have a knot on the back of my head (I'm 5'7"), and the bathtub would not drain unless I jammed a washcloth into the drain to hold the stopper up. The facility itself seemed well-maintained (and the roses lining the walk-ways were beautiful) but the layout is indeed confusing. Our conference put signs with arrows all over the place and I still couldn't find the room half of the time - don't even TRY to find a restroom without asking. On the plus side, the place is SUPER convenient to both the adjacent high-end shopping plaza and the public transportation. I'm so glad that I didn't get a car. I really never needed one. And the dining options in the shopping mall meant that I could easily avoid those in the hotel. The wireless internet service is horrible. And since it isn't handled by the hotel, you can't get the money taken off of your hotel bill. I paid $10 for crawling service. If you needed to check email, you could probably do a batch upload / download while you showered or slept, but I woudn't plan on getting much internet surfing accomplished. Ugh. My biggest complaint, honestly, was how spotty the service was. I had one meal (breakfast buffet) at their casual dining venue, and the waitstaff was great. Cheerful. Friendly. Prompt. I had lunch at their slightly more upscale restaurant and had a terrible experiece. Waited forever for food. Found large chips of metal were coming off my spoon as I ate my soup and had to wander around the restaurant looking for someone to help me. The man I found hardly acknowledged me and never apologized. He just took my soup away and eventually came back with a new spoon and bowl. No offer of anything - not even regret. There are steps up from the main driveway to the lobby and I saw customer after customer struggle to wrangle their luggage up the stairs and through the door while the bell hops chatted inside. Once at the front desk, though, the staff was polite and helpful and friendly. And on my way to the room, I was passed several times by bellhops zipping along in completely empty safari-type shuttle cars - which are apparently on the property to shuttle only the bellhops and never the luggage-toting customers. All in all, it was a confusing experience. I never knew what would be good and what would be bad. And half the time I didn't even know quite where I was. Not a bad place for a family with kids, looking for lots of swimming pools and acreage at a reasonable price, but not that I would consider a quality business-level hotel.

Reviews.Title: “excellent value and location”
Reviews.Author: traveltwentyfour
Reviews.Content: We were staying in the general vicinity and unhappy with our hotel and noticed Town and Country and thought it would be out of our price range. The grounds and pool area looked lovely and the front desk area was also very appealing. Happily, we got an excellent travel industry rate and a very nice room in the tower location on a higher floor towards the ends of the building where the end units angled inward giving us a quieter room. We thought the room had generouse space and looked newly decorated with tasteful funishings. The beds were very comfortable. My room-mate is very picky on cleanliness and suffers from asthma and reacts to any odours and she could not find fault with anything. The location is excellent to the trolley and fashion mall. We could not hesitate to recommend this hotel based on our experience.

Reviews.Title: “Could be worse, could be better”
Reviews.Author: kjnielsen206
Reviews.Content: I was here for a conference like everyone else, plus I stayed for two extra nights for sightseeing etc. The decor of the room is like going to Grandma's house without the smell of Ben-Gay and Vaseline Bath Beads. The layout is very confusing, the maps not to scale and the lanes are unmarked. The food via room service is rather poor and the food you buy at the little on-site shops and cafes is outrageously priced. The parking fee is outrageous. I used the overnight dry cleaning service, my items arrived an hour before my banquet-scary. I asked for a late check out, if you stay 2 hours past, you are changed for a half day, 4 hours-you are charged for an entire day. The good things are the little bridge leading to the Fashion Valley Mall and the trolley station. The grounds are immaculate. Its close to the freeway, Old Town and Hillcrest. I suppose I would come here again for a conference but I would not choose this hotel for my own personal vacation. Its interesting that there is a generic "management response" for the more glowing reviews but none for any criticisms. Hmmmmm?

Reviews.Title: “Superlative experience.”
Reviews.Author: pizano3
Reviews.Content: Clean rooms, very reasonable rates, beautiful outdoor settings. Conveniently located for easy access to all of San Diego's tourist & shopping venues. Management is always courteous and very professional. I travel to San Diego every year and always stay at the Town and Country.

Reviews.Title: “Not that bad, but not that great”
Reviews.Author: beachcomber09
Reviews.Content: Like 95% of the T&C's clientele, I was at the hotel for a conference. I stayed March 10-15 and stayed in the Royal Palm Tower at the north side of the resort. I noticed someone was staying in one of the rooms that face the side of the middle tower... if I had been one room over to the left, I'd be sharing that view. For all those petrified of a horrible view, I'd say maybe 4-6 rooms per floor have the view looking into the side of the middle building, so chances are you'll be just fine. When I went to the T&C, I braced for the utter worst. The front desk was very welcoming and whoever complained about bad customer service either had a bad apple in the lot, or perhaps wasn't the most pleasurable customer to deal with in the first place. The vibe in San Diego is very chilled, and i highly suggest that visitors adopt this vibe too! The location is very central to the city, interstate, and trolley. I did my fair share of research on public transportation in San Diego and opted to take transit rather than rent a car. I'm used to the very slow transit service of Ottawa, Canada, so the San Diego system was great for me. The Green Line trolley from the hotel runs every 7-15 min depending on the day/time and you can connect to the Blue Line trolley in Old Town to go to downtown San Diego. Most days it took 20-25 min to get into the heart of San Diego from the Fashion Valley Transit Center. Speaking of Fashion Valley, there is an EXCELLENT mall right behind the Town and Country that is also home to PF Chang's, Uno Chicago Grill, and the Cheesecake Factory (plus food court restaurants and a McDonalds), so if you ever need a break from hotel food, there's lots nearby. If you do have a car, within 2 miles there's every restaurant and fast food joint you can dream of. I didn't eat at the hotel once the whole time i was there (someone mentioned high prices), so I can't comment on the food. The rooms... oh the rooms. Firstly, I'd like to say that the infamous picture of the creepy girl was NOT present in my room and someone said she used to be in every room, so that's good news. The rest, not so much. While the rooms were clean enough, the rooms were reminiscent of "grandma's", so be prepared for some 50s country decor. The rooms also didn't have a safe, which may bother some people (I personally locked my documents in my suitcase). The air conditioning took a little while to kick in and the maid turned mine off while I was out of my room one day, so I came back after a long, hot run to discover my room temperature warmer than the outside temperature. And yes, the showerhead is quite low, but I'm 6'0" and I didn't have an issue slightly bending my knees to wash my hair. And you can go shower cap-less if you don't want to wash your hair! The layout of the hotel is a little confusing, but just walk in the general direction of where you want to go and I'm sure you'll get there just fine. This isn't a great hotel if you have a lower extremity injury and can't walk more than 300-500 ft, but it's always good to get a little exercise -- especially on vacation. In regards to parking, as I mentioned, I didn't have a car, but the Royal Palm parking lot was never totally full and there were always spots. Someone said the hotel was fully booked, so it seemed to be alright as far as parking goes. A good suggestion -- if you really don't mind taking public transit around (it's very convenient at the hotel), I highly recommend not renting a car. Parking at the hotel was up to $14/day, and I managed to get a 4-day trolley/bus pass for $15. This may be more directed to the economy traveller, but it is something to consider! Always good to go green! Finally, I do want to mention that the pools and grounds of the hotel were lovely. Grass was always cut and the flowers were beautiful, even for a cool March. The pool was heated so even on nights when it was 50F, swimming was a pleasure! If anyone has any questions on the Town and Country, San Diego, or transportation, I'd be glad to help! Please e-mail me at annebenyon@yahoo.ca Have a good trip!

Reviews.Title: “Not *that* bad, and definintely unique”
Reviews.Author: KDUB7
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the T&C for a conference (does anyone stay there for any other reason?) I thought it was OK - yeah, the decor is about 20+ years out of date, but my room was clean, quiet, and safe. I awoke each morning to the sounds of birds. Loved the gardens, and liked being able to walk back to my room in between sessions. The layout is confusing at first, though: take your map with you! Location is very convenient - with the trolley stop just across the street, one doesn't even need a car.

Reviews.Title: “A time warp into the 50's & 60's”
Reviews.Author: vicPlano_TX
Reviews.Content: All of these reviews need some perspective. We were there for a small convention for four nights. This is not your usual hotel. It's a mish-mash of one and two floor outside entry motel rooms with a couple of dated hotel towers, with a multi-stage-built convention center. Most of those making reviews here aren't old enough to remember the motels of the 50's and 60's. This place has managed to keep those places alive in one place. Except they charged $12/day to park in rather under-sized spaces. Finding your way around was extremely frustrating since the map wasn't to scale and none of the "lanes" were marked, and the room numbers weren't on the buildings, just the doors. The upkeep was very good in general and the rooms were clean. But they are just stuffed full of beds, gaudy drapes, and valences and tv cabinet clutter. The closet was a hint of one. To get to the front wall a/c, it meant either squeezing between the bed and the front wall or plopping onto the bed next to that wall. Luckily, it didn't get very warm because that a/c was pretty weak. The bathroom area was amusing. That is, if you could chuckle at the toilet paper roll almost in your lap as you sat there. Large people might put holes in the wall with their elbows. That's because the walls were like thick paper. I could hear the guy in the next room coughing and the lady in the room above also coughing and making other "noises" in the bathroom. Kind of funny at times. You could almost name those by the sound. Yes, they charged $9.95 for wireless internet, that wasn't very high speed. Not a bad place by any means, the staff was very attentive and friendly. Would I stay there again? Only if the Residence Inn on the other side of the freeway was sold out.

Reviews.Title: “Convention by day, Old Town by night via Trolley”
Reviews.Author: thai2007
Reviews.Content: I'll agree with the other positive reviews posted by other conference attendees, but my main remark that does not appear to be addressed in this forum is the ease with which you can get in and out of the property after a day's conferences to enjoy San Diego, even without a car. The Trolley couldn't be easier to use, the clean, well lit station (with automated ticketing) located immediately behind the property, on the pedestrian path to the Fashion Valley mall. We never waited more than 10 minutes, and ran directly into Old Town Station well into the evening, with a transfer to the downtown line, all for a $5 day pass. Much better than most other convention-style resorts that do everything in their power to keep you on property, it was refreshing to be able to explore with the convenience of the Trolley at the end of a long day of seminars.

Reviews.Title: “Don't stay here!!”
Reviews.Author: Starb1
Reviews.Content: We booked through the Smooth Jazz Cruise. We were told that we were going to be staying in a "garden room". The grounds were acceptable. The one jacuzzi for this very large old property was closed due to renovation. Understandable since it was due for a renovation. But one jacuzzi for all these people? The "garden room" was horrendous. The bathtub stained, the decor was a bad version of American Heritage??, not sure what to call it. As I wanted to relax in hot water and there was no jacuzzi, we went to the desk requesting a room with a clean tub. We were moved but as we were in the lobby we observed the staff taking complaint after complaint from people arriving and seeing the state of their rooms. We had to stay here as we had no car which we thought was not necessary since this was a resort with restaurants, many amenities and a smooth jazz land festival all weekend to entertain us. We tried to find other accomodations close by but their was no availibility or affordable ones due to a nurses convention in town. One restaurant's food was not good. So we didn't try the others. The Convention Center was beautiful. It was obvious that's where all their money is going. They need to use some to renovate the "garden" rooms and the buildings outside as well. The rest of the staff were not very friendly probably due to being yelled at all day by the guests. The hotel manager was very sympathetic and helped us out by taking one night rate off our bill. We filled out a survey and the hotel also sent us a letter of apology.

Reviews.Title: “Another Positive Experience!”
Reviews.Author: btboop
Reviews.Content: I wholeheartedly agree with the positive experiences reported on by the recent reviewer from southern Minnesota! I have just returned home from having attended a conference at the Town and Country from February 13-16, 2008. I too had read many less than favourable reviews about the resort, and so was not quite sure what to expect. However, my companions and I were more than pleasantly surprised by the facilities, service, and staff at the resort, and I was resolved to write my own positive review after returning home. We arrived at the resort shortly after noon on our day of arrival to find that our room was not yet ready (check-in isn't supposed to be until 3 PM, after all). The only room available was one without a view (the brick wall mentioned by other reviewers), and so we opted to wait for another. The front desk staff were most apologetic, and quickly called for the bell captain to store our luggage until later. As it happened, we did not have to wait until 3 PM for our room; our luggage was retrieved and we were transported by golf cart to the Royal Palm Tower. Derek then brought our luggage right up to our room for us, too! Our double room on the 9th floor was directly off the elevator lobby, but we were never disturbed by noise from the elevator, guests in adjoining rooms, or the freeway. We had a lovely view of the entire resort and the surrounding hills from our balcony, which was furnished with a white wrought iron table and chairs. Our room was quite spacious, and was furnished with dark colonial-style furniture. The 2 queen-sized beds were separated by a writing desk and chair, 2 armchairs flanked another round table, a long dressing bench sat under the picture of the little girl in the blue dress (very cute!), and an armoire housed the TV over three drawers for clothing. The dark blue carpet looked to be quite new, and the bedspreads matched the draperies and pleated valances over the beds. Our room also had a second sink and counter in the dressing area outside the bathroom - very handy when three women are sharing a room! The mirrored sliding doors on the closet were appreciated, as was the heatlamp on a timer in the bathroom. The weather on one day of our stay was cool and rainy - between 45 & 50 degrees - but the heat in our room worked very well to keep us absolutely comfortable. By the way, a photo posted by another reviewer is a bit misleading: of course all of the rooms in the Royal Palm Tower have windows! The photo is actually a shot of the open-air corridors along the BACK side of the tower from which the rooms are accessed. We were very impressed by the conference facilities at the Town and Country. In addition to the main exhibit hall and ballrooms, the resort has a multitude of break-out rooms of various sizes. Sumptuous carpets, mirrors, and crystal chandeliers adorn the foyers, and the restrooms feature marble countertops and tiled floors. The banks of smaller meeting rooms are separated by walkways bordered by well-kept flowerbeds and many benches and tables for further conversation. The only caution I would give regarding the facilities is that the sheer size of the resort requires quite a bit of walking back and forth from your accommodations to various conference facilities - a consideration for anyone with mobility issues. We also enjoyed our meals at the Town & Country Resort. The breakfast buffet at the Terrace Cafe does offer a good variety of hot and cold choices - certainly more than we could eat - and the regular menu for all meals has something for everyone. Our final dinner at Trellises Garden Grille was more expensive, but was delicious and beautifully presented. I can't say enough about the two banquets we enjoyed - one of roast beef and the other of chicken breasts stuffed with spinach! Beautifully cooked - beef still pink inside, vegetables crisp-tender, all piping hot, despite service for over 1000 attendees! Prompt service by unfailingly pleasant and accommodating wait staff. Oh, and the desserts! TOO decadent! We found that the Town & Country Resort was located quite centrally for all of our needs. It was only a 10-15 minute shuttle ride from the airport, and was a maximum 5-10 minute walk from the Fashion Valley trolley stop. It was quite easy to take the trolley system downtown to Seaport Village. And the Fashion Valley Mall begins just the other side of the transit centre/trolley stop. In summary, I would not hesitate to visit the Town & Country Resort again. The facility is quite charming and very clean, and the flowers and landscaping are beautiful. The staff were unfailingly pleasant and eager to assist whenever needed. My only regret is that our conference was not longer!

Reviews.Title: “A Positive Experience at the Town and Country!”
Reviews.Author: gjkov
Reviews.Content: After reading all the negative reviews, we were also more than a bit apprehensive about our stay at the Town and Country. But since that is where our conference was being held, we had little choice. So we went into it trying to have as positive an attitude as we could, and I am pleased to say we were delighted to have had a very different experience. It was almost as if we were staying at a different resort! Please bear with a rather long review, as we feel weâ€™d like to share the positives. We are simple middle class people who do a fair amount of traveling, mostly staying in mid range accomodations (Marriott, Hilton Garden Inns and Hamptons, Holiday Inns and the like). From the moment we arrived, all the staff was never anything but pleasant and helpful. This included the front desk, cleaning and other support people, restaurant staff, concierge staff, conference center people, as well as several higher level managers we encountered and talked with one day. I can honestly say we never encountered a crabby staff person during the week. We were booked in the Royal Palm tower, and having read about some of the rooms with views of brick walls, we specifically requested a middle room with balcony overlooking the pool area when checking in. We were nicely accommodated with this requestâ€¦.as with the few others we made during our stay. When we got to our room we found we were close to the elevatorâ€¦which we had read was a problem for another reviewer in regard to noise. But we were never disturbed by noise from the elevator or any of the rooms around us. We never even heard any noise from the rooms around us and we knew people were staying in them. There was staff with golf carts to help you bring your bags to your room, if needed. We had a rental car, so did not need that service, but we never had trouble finding a convenient parking spot, as some other reviewers spoke of. We could see that there were not as many parking spots by the garden bungalows, so maybe was not as easy to park there, but we never had any trouble in the big lot by the Royal Palm. And some spoke of roads within the resort that were hard to navigate, but we never had trouble with that. It is a rather big place, but not that big. It was a nice, couple minute walk from our building to the lobby area, which were on opposite ends of the resort. Our Royal Palm room was very spacious and nicely appointed; with a king bed, easy chair and ottoman, small table and chair as well as a writing desk. There was also the armoire with TV, bed tables and both floor and table lamps in various locations around the room that provided good lighting. The balcony had 2 comfortable padded chairs and a small table and we enjoyed time out there every day. The bathroom was spacious and had an outer area with a counter and sink, as well as the sink in the actual bathroom. I will agree that the shower head was mounted very low, but if that was the worst thing wrong, we certainly could easily deal with it. There was a large closet, too, with plenty of hangers. And though the comforter was not of a design I would choose for my bed at home (as with most hotels), it was certainly not objectionable. And besides being comfortable, the room was very clean and cleaned nicely each day throughout our stay. I read a number of reviews that mentioned the proximity of the freeway. And while it did run close to the front of the resort and we could see the traffic from our balcony, we could barely hear any noise with it. Even in early morning when the resort was very quiet, so it never disturbed us in the least. Was it very scenic? Not really and certainly not like looking at the ocean, but those rooms on the coast have much heftier price tags attached, too. And since the layout of the resort was so nice; with trees, lovely gardens and flowers, pools, etc, it was not hard to overlook the freeway. The grounds were also kept very clean. There were always cleaning crews out first thing in the morning cleaning the pool and other common areas. And besides doing a great job, they were also quick to return a smile and a greeting. The pools and whirlpool looked very clean and though we did not use them, heard many good things from folks in our conference who did. There was some construction going on, as they were renovating some areas, but it was very easy to get around and did not disturb us in any way. Food at the resort was a little on the expensive side, but no more so than in other restaurants we ate in around San Diego. And all the food we had was very well prepared, portions more than adequate and wait staff very pleasant. The breakfast buffet was especially nice, with good hot food and many choices; scrambled eggs, potatoes, bacon, sausage, pancakes, french toast, beautiful fresh fruit, cereals and a multitude of bread and pastry choices. Some thought it was a little expensive at $14.50, but included all beverages, so really was not much more than breakfast with juice and coffee at someplace like Perkins and was all you could eat. The Terrace also had nice salads, sandwiches and great homemade soups along with some other entrees and a fresh fish choice each day, making it a good choice for any meal of the day. The Trellis is a little more upscale and rather expensive for dinner (we thought), but we had a very nice lunch there. Kellyâ€™s Steakhouse has nice dinner offerings in midrange pricing. We never ate at Charlieâ€™s but heard from others it was also quite good. You can also easily walk over to the mall, which has a variety of restaurants in all price ranges. The convention center was large, but once you got the lay of the land, it was not hard to navigate. The convention staff was also very nice and the meals we were provided during our conference were excellent! All in all we had a very good experience with the Town and Country and loved our stay in San Diego.

Reviews.Title: “A rebuttal of the great staff I experienced”
Reviews.Author: JimmyR
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Town and Country for 8 days in the last week of January, 2008 while at a week long convention. I was somewhat worried about the booking due to the recent negative comments on this site and thought I should provide my input. Due to flight issues I arrived at 2:30 AM and went to room 1928....I opened the curtains and I was staring at the infamous concrete wall with no view other than brick work. I called down to the front desk and asked to be placed on a list to change rooms as this room was not acceptable. I was met with a friendly voice and told she would place me on the list and I could change in the morning. I went to the front desk around 11:00 and was guaranteed I would get a different room but they needed to wait for an update as to what rooms had been vacated and cleaned. I went back at 2:30 and was placed in 1132, an excellent ground floor room that actually walked out to a large patio that I used everyday. I used room service on three occasions and found the food to be of good quality and reasonably priced. And a large pizza is really large....and will feed 4 people easily. A co-worker requested a room change later in the week as her spouse was arriving with their 18 month old......this was handled with ease and they were allocated a room close by to us so that they could sit outside at night and use their baby monitor to llisten to their child. All in all, I would return to this hotel for the location and accomodating staff.

Reviews.Title: “Shocking”
Reviews.Author: Davinibus
Reviews.Content: This place is dire. The food is rubbish, the room service arrives cold, the location is not the greatest, 'entertainment' is a joke. Its like staying on the set of Dirty Dancing... wrong, wrong, wrong. The only highlight was sitting in the Piano Bar listening to the local pensioners singing show tunes from the 1940's. In hindsight it must have been a highlight thanks to the copious amount of beers i drank. Do not stay here, stay in a more central location downtown. You may miss out on the pool, but you'll gain so much more in terms of fun.

Reviews.Title: “Would not stay here again; very mediocre hotel and cold front office”
Reviews.Author: experiencedtrvlr32
Reviews.Content: My office booked the hotel for the night before I actually was to be there. Front office was cold and didn't seem to care when I checked in and when I asked if they could please consider not charging me for the extra night. They said I was a no show and that was their policy. I was there for a professional meeting and had stayed there several times before but they indicated this was their policy with no exceptions. The fitness facility is extremely outdated and yet it charges $8.00 for use even if one isn't using the spa. The bicycles stick and one can't even listen to one's own music since the bikes are so old. There are no elliptical machines. When I complained, the spa desk just smiled and gave me a comments card. The hotel room had no facial tissue and no shower cap. The walls are not well insulated so noise from the room above (even though I was in the renovated section) are very audible.

Reviews.Title: “Conveniently Locatedâ€¦But Then, So Is Hell”
Reviews.Author: Yobabs
Reviews.Content: Our family converged on San Diego for a small reunion from December 27-30, 2007. My brother, a San Diego resident, made reservations for us at the Town & Country, via Expedia, months ahead of time. He also used Expedia to pay, and to request 4 double queen rooms. At check-in, we were given four double queen rooms, but told that we would have to move to different rooms after the first night. No explanation was given at the time, but we were told by Javier, the night manager, that the new rooms would be an upgrade, that they would be double queens, and that he would comp our three daysâ€™ parking (parking is a hefty $14/day) and two daysâ€™ breakfasts. Now, when I arrive at a hotel, I really want to unpack and settle in - and I donâ€™t want to worry about packing again until itâ€™s time to leave. I absolutely detest the unsettled feeling of staying one night here and one night there, even if itâ€™s different rooms in the same hotel. So Javierâ€™s news that we would be moving after the first night was anything but welcome. The comps were something, as was his assurance that weâ€™d be getting better rooms, but bottom line, they werenâ€™t worth the hassle we were looking at in changing rooms. The property is huge and sprawling. Itâ€™s like a small community, albeit a community that never understood the point of a planning commission. Thereâ€™s a bit of parking here, a bit there, and even a parking structure â€“ but we didnâ€™t see an actual entrance to that, so it didnâ€™t do us any good. We drove to the building where our four rooms were located, and circled the surrounding area a couple of times looking for parking, but there was none within the same Zip code as the rooms; we ended up parking just this side of Tijuana. To add to our delight, the rooms were on the second floor of a somewhat ratty old building, with no elevator, so once we humped our bags from the car to the building, we hauled them up an outdoor concrete staircase. It was starting to dawn on us that this was not so much a hotel, as a motel with pretensions. The rooms were small, a bit shabby, and one had a funny smell that gave my daughter a headache within seconds of entering, but they were non-smoking double queen rooms, and all four of our rooms were in the same small cell-block, er, building. The room design was a bit odd; I didnâ€™t even find the closet for several hours. (Note: in my defense, I didnâ€™t actually spend those hours searching for a closet. When I didnâ€™t spot one right off the bat, I just assumed there wasnâ€™t one, and was therefore surprised to discover one later, sort of tucked behind the sink.) There was no point in unpacking, but there was not sufficient space to accommodate an open suitcase, as we were being thrown out the next morning anyway. We finally cleared the hotelâ€™s junk from the wooden table to put an open suitcase on it. I awoke early the next morning, increasingly frustrated at how we were being treated. In particular, it kept going through my mind that the only reason for moving us from our block of four rooms was that the hotel was more interested in accommodating the new guests than in making our group happy. At around 6, I got dressed and ventured to the lobby to see if they could do any better for us. I spoke with Christina at the desk. On a map, she showed me where our new rooms would be, circling an area encompassing multiple buildings, while she tried to sound like the rooms were somehow close together. She, too, assured me that we would have double queen rooms. I mentioned the lack of convenient parking, and she pointed out a number of parking lots around the periphery of the property. Perhaps there were parking spaces in those far-flung lots; perhaps there are parking spaces on the moon, too, but they wouldnâ€™t do us much good, being nowhere near our rooms. Anyway, Christina said that they would make the move as hassle-free as they could, and we at least wouldnâ€™t have to wait through the check-in line again. After packing what little weâ€™d bothered to unpack, we had breakfast at the buffet at the Terraces. It was a typical breakfast buffet, with scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, pancakes, etc. Nothing special (e.g., no omelet bar), but it was OK. A couple of notes to remember: if you like to enjoy a beverage with your meal, order it before you visit the buffet; otherwise, it will arrive about the time you leave. Also, the nearest restrooms are located in the convention center (i.e., nowhere in the Terraces building), so plan accordingly. We checked out of our rooms (we had to go to the desk for this: for some reason, they couldnâ€™t just transfer the account information without seeing our by-now snarling faces), and we checked our bags with the bell desk. After spending the day out, we came back to check in to the new rooms. Not only did they need to see our faces, but they needed to see our IDâ€™s in order to do this, so we had to have one representative from each room turn up, with ID, at the desk. No idea why. The funny thing was, they enforced this ID thing with some of our rooms, but not all. They did have our keys all ready, and we trooped off to the new four rooms, which were located, respectively, here, over there, way over there, and way the hell over there. Thanks ever so much for the effort, Christina. The new rooms were, indeed, nicer. They were on the ground floor and were larger. However, each had a just one king-size bed, despite the assurances of both Javier-the-night-manager and Christina-the-morning-desk-person that weâ€™d have double queens. So as soon as we looked at the first room, we called the front desk to see what was up. This time, the story was different. The person on the line said that she had no idea why Javier and Christina had both promised double queen rooms; according to her, both Javier and Christina should have known, at the time they were making their promises, that no such rooms would be available to us. Now, if we wanted to move again the next day (call the Guinness Book of Records â€“ three rooms in three days!), they could accommodate us. The bottom line was, we now had four rooms, each with a king bed in it, and, as the hotel had nothing more appropriate to offer us, we requested rollaways to be brought in ASAP. As it transpired, the term â€œASAPâ€� didnâ€™t mean much to the staff â€“ they brought them at such a leisurely pace that we left for dinner not knowing whether there would be adequate bedding when we got back that night. In fact, one granddaughter ended up in tears, as Grandma had to cancel a planned sleepover because she didnâ€™t know whether there would be another bed in her room. By then, I was really getting mad. I told the person on the phone that they should be looking at comping rooms at this point. She said they couldnâ€™t, as the reservations were made via Expedia â€“ and that our requests for double queens were only requests, and did not have to be honored, since they, too, had been made via Expedia. My pointing out that two hotel employees, one of them a manager, had promised double queens, didnâ€™t make a dent. (Note to self: Self, in future, never book a hotel via Expedia; maybe use it to search, but book via the hotel directly.) The new rooms were pretty, but noisy. Each had a nice big bay window, which, I think, was the reason why anyone walking by, conversing in normal tones, sounded like they were right in our room, conversing via megaphones. Also, the shower head was mounted so low that, even though Iâ€™m only 5â€™5â€�, I had to kneel to wash my hair. (And no, it wasnâ€™t like that in order to accommodate folks with disabilities â€“ if that were the reason, there would have been handrails. It was just mounted at a stupid height.) Now, to be fair, I must say that they did supply some of those little extras that really make a trip memorable. For instance, one of our four rooms came complete with a dirty diaper; it was on top of the armoire, along with the rest of the trash left by the previous occupants. And another room had a little touch of the beach in it: sand all over the tub. Given that a rinse was all it took to clean out the sand, it was clear that the maids had not bothered to rinse the tub, let alone properly clean it, even between guests. Glad I opted for a shower. The bottom line here is that the Town & Country is woefully mismanaged, and staffed by folks who will look you in the eye, smile, and lie their guts out. The cleaning crew couldnâ€™t get a job mucking out a pig sty. There are thousands and thousands of hotel rooms on Hotel Circle in San Diego; if the only vacancies are at the Town & Countryâ€¦well, try another city. San Franciscoâ€™s nice.

Reviews.Title: “Quaint and luxurious”
Reviews.Author: SF_egret
Reviews.Content: This is a fun place--a sprawling property with lovely gardens, multiple restaurants, little cottage-style rooms around courtyards and a few tower blocks of hotel rooms. There are palm trees, gazebos, rose bushes everywhere, and something like 4 picturesque swimming pools. There is a really fancy spa with a nice fitness center too. Right behind the hotel is part of the San Diego River, and a bridge over that river takes one to a posh shopping center (Fashion Valley). My room was a sweet little cottage room with cherry wood colonial style furniture and a dark blue carpet. There was a huge four-poster bed, nice little writing desk, and a table by the bay window with two lovely big chairs. It opened directly out into a little courtyard with palm trees, a gazebo, lawn and rosebushes. It was a beautiful room, and a lovely, peaceful place to stay. I enjoyed walking around the grounds at night and in the morning--it was very well maintained. Weird stuff: Two of the more casual restaurants were shut when I was staying there, and the one that was open was too fancy for a person in casual clothes so I had to order (pricey) room service instead. Also, you have to pay for every little extra you would expect for free from other hotels, such as in-room internet service, parking in front of your own room (!?) and use of the fitness center. The fitness center is really a good one, but yeesh, uses is usually free at most other places. Good perks: On the south side of the river a block or two east of the hotel, you can get onto a very beautiful running path that goes for miles along the San Diego River. It's like a dream it is so pretty in the morning and you would never even believe you were running near a major highway and a lot of upscale shopping centers. Part of it goes past posh condos, but some of it is a little more isolated. It is paved and at one point there is also a path along the northside of the river. It was spectacular. You can also access the trolley from near the hotel, which is pretty cool.

Reviews.Title: “Sleep in your car!!!!”
Reviews.Author: mdog002
Reviews.Content: This hotel was used for overflow from a conference at the Marriott near the stadium. I recall the hotel from the early 70's when it was exceptional. I checked in quickly and went to the assigned room. The new digital thermostat did not work! Spent a cold night in the room. About 3 a.m. I have a "scratchy" feeling on my feet. I get up pull the blankets back and find a full-size sheet on the king-size mattress. I report the issues to the desk in the moring, 6:30 a.m. Upon return at 5:30 p.m. nothing fixed or changed. I respond to the desk and get a new room. I remove the blankets from the king bed...guess what...the same deal; the sheets are 12" too short for the mattress. The TV didn't work either...but there was heat this time, if you could make it across the floor for the broken glass left by housekeeping. Oh, BTW, a door prize of a two-day stay at the Town & Country Hotel is refused by the gentleman whose name is called. Everyone had a good laugh at that one. Interesting, the staff never seemed the least bit interested in the problems!!! STAY, STAY, STAY AWAY

Reviews.Title: “Very Poor Customer Service”
Reviews.Author: EDHTraveler9
Reviews.Content: The customer service at ths hotel is TERRIBLE/Non existent. I was visiting my daughter who is a student at SDSU (the SDSU website lists this hotel for discounts to SDSU parents.) Besides the decor - which is very outdated, I did not like that fact that you had to park in a gated parking lot and that you have to get a ticket from the attendant and present that each time you leave the lot. Also, the jacuzzi was under construction at the time of our stay, so we could not use it - but we were never told of this fact when we made our reservation or when we checked in. However - the biggest problem was when we checked out. Several hours after leaving the hotel I realized that I had left 2 jackets in the closet and my cell phone charger plugged in by the table. I called the hotel immediately and was told to speak with Janet in the Lost and Found department. Nothing was turned in that day and Janet said she would call me back with an update. Needless to say, several weeks later, no call back from Janet, so I called the hotel and asked to speak with a manager. After a run-around on the phone speaking with people who really just didn't seem to care, I got through to Mr. Sobek's office, the General Manager, and left him a message. He did follow up on my message by having one of his security officers call me back. My things were never found and when I pushed the issue the security officer offered to write up a report. Since I never heard back from Mr. Sobek directly I called him again and was able to speak with him in person. He did say that they had checked the lock records and according to that , no one but the 'room attendant' had entered my room that day. Basically he said they had done all that they could do and sorry that they never called me back and sorry that they don't know what happened to my things but that was really all they could do. No urgency, no offer to follow up on the matter, no real caring about the situation. When I pushed the issue Mr. Sobek stated that they often are accused of their staff stealing things from the rooms. At no time did I accuse anyone of stealing anything. My issue is that the hotel staff did not appear to take this matter seriously and that is what truly concerns me. Before this incident I had decided that I would never stay at this property again - mostly due to personal taste - but this issue is more serious and I warn travelers to be careful! To add insult to injury, during my phone call with Mr. Sobek, he basically hung up on me once he said 'goodbye', I didn't even have a chance to say 'goodbye' myself. I do find it interesting that the security officer offered to write up a report for me but Mr. Sobek didn't. Does he not know of the procedures in his own hotel? I don't doubt for a second that hotel management is a tough job, but customer service is the name of the game and this hotel should acknowledge that!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful and Comfortable”
Reviews.Author: WestHollywood24
Reviews.Content: The Town & Country offers a choice of high-rise and low-rise. We always stay here when we visit family in San Diego and we've stayed in both and like both. The grounds are landscaped with rose bushes galore and kept in perfect condition. Walk out of your gound-level room and sit in your own little terrace. You have a choice of restaurants on the property plus a breakfast/lunch trolley. The rooms are comfortable. The service is outstanding. At the rear of the property is a stop on the local light rail line that will take you downtown. Also cross the bridge over the stream to a major mall which includes Bloomingdale's and Saks Fifth Avenue. Barry Parker and Jerry Rutledge

Reviews.Title: “Not so bad! Really nice staff”
Reviews.Author: TravelinGal45
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed here for a convention-I had read the reviews and so I had low expectations-someone had suggested I stay in one of the garden area rooms and I was happy I followed that suggestion as I was quite pleased with the room and its location-everything was clean, the room was very comfortable, and staff here were really accomodating-the property is large, and staff was happy to give a ride to my room (including with luggage in tow and bought it up to the room). I had a superb meal at one of the restaurants on grounds-I also enjoyed being able to walk over to the fancy mall nearby(Tiffanys, Barneys, Bose, Coach), etc...The massage I had at their lovely spa was heavenly!Lastly, I was able to get on a wonderful trolley to tour the city and found the location of the hotel to be pretty good-. This is a great place for the business traveller-If I return with my family, I would probably stay in Coronado, or more in the center of the city-

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed our Stay at Town and Country”
Reviews.Author: A10Hawaii
Reviews.Content: Very convenient location as it was very close to the freeway, which provided easy access to and from the hotel. We were in the Royal Palm Tower which was within walking distance to the Fashion Valley Mall. Parking was easy and very close to the rooms, although there is an extra charge for parking. We found it strange, however, that there was a semi-truck parked at the far end of the parking lot ,with a mean looking guard dog chained to it. The rooms were not fancy but were clean and well kept. Lobby is in a physically separate building and you have to drive to your room after checking in. They don't offer baggage service to your room. All in all, we had an enjoyable experience and would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible Experience”
Reviews.Author: RileyFinn
Reviews.Content: The decor of the hotel was beyond belief! There is a picture of a little girl in a blue dress who stares at you in your bed. Her eyes follow you throughout the room. We were told by the staff that this picture is in every room of the hotel because the lady in charge decided that the girl looks like her daughter. We were also told by one of the guests who studied Art History that the painting of the girl is studied in Art History classes because shortly after the painting was commissioned the young girl committed suicide. The staff very openly hate working there so there is little customer service offered. I do not recommend this hotel. Many people complained during our stay of the painting of the creepy girl and how they put a towel over the painting since it is glued to the wall. The hotel is dirty, dingy and decorated in poor taste. If you decide to stay here, do not expect to feel comfortable.

Reviews.Title: “Large but enjoyable”
Reviews.Author: MinamiRinkan
Reviews.Content: Each time I have stayed (for conferences) it has generally been a positive experience. Staff helpfulness is improving. Rooms are clean but basic for the price. Cost of internet access is expensive, 10.95 per day for wifi. Conference facilities are good. The grounds are large and very lovely with older, bungalow style buildings, which are reminiscent of mid-1900s California. I avoid staying in the multistory buildings. Highly recommend the steaks at Kellyâ€™s. The service there is also excellent.

Reviews.Title: “it's one of our favorite places”
Reviews.Author: hrqueen
Reviews.Content: You should be aware that it's an older facility with lots of charm. My daughter and I stay frequently due to the location, the pools, and just to get away from our daily routine. I'm really tired of the comments regarding the costs - others must not be from California nor use to what hotel costs will be anytime you are close to the ocean, it's reasonable. Food has always been good, whether it is snacks, burgers or in the restaurants and the cost is equivalent to most resorts. My daughter likes having the the options of going to the exercise room and/or spa and I like the pool area. We have always stayed in the Royal tower in the back of the property to be close to the food and pool, but it's also a quick walk to a great mall. Rooms are clean, well keep and our favorite item is the private terrace, that's what I go for - not many hotels have them anymore! Also, every time I have stayed the parking charge never cost what some have complained about - maybe I'm just use to all hotels having a charge and there is security all around the facility. I will definitely be going back sometime.

Reviews.Title: “Rip Van Winkle Tired...and then some”
Reviews.Author: capoidog
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 3 days, 2 nights. Everything was beat up, smelly, worn and torn. The wallpaper was peeling, the carpet was a disaster and the ambiance was non existent. There was no hot water in the Regency tower and everything smelled on the fifth floor like vomit. The staff was nice enough, but the place needs a bulldozer a lot more than a makeover.

Reviews.Title: “1970s and not in a retro-hip way”
Reviews.Author: Antsy280
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Town and Country in August 2007 for a conference. Overall, this felt like a well-worn, 1970s hotel that is badly in need of some updating. The only thing I enjoyed about this hotel was the pool. If you stay here, you should absolutely stay in the royal palm tower, many of the garden rooms looked quite dark. Ask for a room with a view of the pool. My first room was in the tower, but the balcony had a view of a brick wall, and it was DARK! (See picture) I asked to be changed to a room with a pool view on the 6th floor. It was better. Good things: Lots of pools, easy to find a seat, close to a big mall and the trolley. Wireless internet is available for $10/day. You can extend checkout until 6pm for half of your daily room rate. Bad things: weird location (right on a big highway), no real view (I had a view of the pool and the highway), dark rooms, room decor is very old-school English which doesn't fit with a San Diego resort, there are some outdated resort features (empty hair salon?).

Reviews.Title: “It was nice to be back”
Reviews.Author: BAJAFRIEND
Reviews.Content: We stayted at the Hotel for one night only. I have stayed at this Resort many times in the past. The Resort accommodates my needs very well wether I am in business or pleasure. This was my wife's first visit and she fell in love with the beautifully manicured grounds, the cleanliness of the common areas and the impecables housekeeping job in the room we were assigned to. Although the hotel's front office personnel was very occupied with the registration of a convention we were serviced on courtesly, promptly and efficiently. I like the changes made on the rennovated rooms, they have a lor of character and the rooms blend with the rest of the resort's theme. The food and beverage out lets maintain they excellent service and food quality while prices are reasonable. One can notice that the high standars, quality and consistency are the result of a low ratio turn over, a substantial number of the employees thoroughout have been with the organization for several years. I know that if ever in the area again I will return to the Town and Country Resort with out hesitation. Sincerely, Mario A. CortÃ©s G.

Reviews.Title: “Retro, but not in a good way”
Reviews.Author: babyrn2005
Reviews.Content: This place needs a serious overhaul. The grounds are beautiful and must be worth a fortune in sunny San Diego, but the facilities leave a lot to be desired. Our room was a double in the Royal Palm tower overlooking the pool with a nice little balcony. Except when you looked up, there was peeling paint staring at you! The wallpaper in the room looks like it was hung in the 70's and the decor matches. The air conditioning ran, but the room stayed humid. All of my papers were crinkled from the moistness. The front desk staff was mixed. One day they were very helpful and the next they were clueless. I guess that some of them were new to their positions. The bell service was good and the meeting facilities for my conference were adequate. Since I was attending a conference there, it was convenient but I would not stay there under any other circumstances.

Reviews.Title: “Great Experience All Around”
Reviews.Author: BNBSunland
Reviews.Content: Even though we saw some rather negative reviews for this property, we gave it a try. The main reason for this was the last minute nature of our vacation, and limited availability at other resorts. We booked two rooms in the Royal Palms Tower. The resort is beautiful, clean and well maintained. The buildings are not new, and the style of the structures is a bit dated, but the same is true of many fine resorts in California. The rooms have been freshly redecorated, and they are stylish and more than comfortable. The vast majority of the staff we met was polite and attentive. We tried a few of the restaurants and room service. The food was very tasty, and the service was great. Since the resort is not all inclusive, we tried several of the restaurants outside the resort, and there are many, many restaurants in the immediate area. The spa, La Bella Tosca, is beautiful, and the services I purchased were professionally administered and very satisfying. Since the resort caters to business travellers, the pools and restaurants were not crowded, and families were able to enjoy all of the facilities with little or no waiting. The resort is located such that all of the area's attractions are easy to access. All in all, this was a very pleasant experience. I would absolutely go back again, and I would recommend this resort to others.

Reviews.Title: “Handicap Accessibility”
Reviews.Author: FredSacramento
Reviews.Content: A 3 day conference was planned for Planning Commissioners and was held at the Town and Country Resort in San Diego. I requested that the City I represente to book me into a handicap accessible room and I was very pleased with the room, shower and accessibility of my reservation. The shower was definitely designed for the handicapped. All of the staff at Town and Country were very helpful in aiding me during my stay in San Diego and I higly recommend them for their help. Ernest Vance

Reviews.Title: “Welcome to the 1970's!”
Reviews.Author: IowaSdz
Reviews.Content: Not good! An extremely dated property in desperate need of updates. Rooms on the ground floor ("Garden Suites") were dark, dank, and loud. (They originally tried to put me in a room with only a murphy bed!) A friend stayed in the the "Royal Palm" and had a view of a brick wall. There are actually no windows on 3 sides of that building. We had a convention there, and everything was so difficult to find it was unbelievable.
